title: Based on the evidence, do you think the decision brought today in the Breonna Taylor case was just? - Quora

response.answer_text: The Breonna Taylor case is a real anomaly. It’s also a very sad case. I am not a fan of no-knock warrants. The Taylor case is a perfect example of why. Taylor’s boyfriend saw home intruders in blacked out clothing inside his home without warning. He thought, “I have the right to defend my home.” He didn’t know these are cops. But the cops had the right to defend themselves as well. Shots are fired and Breonna Taylor was killed by a stray bullet. This is not a clear-cut case of murder. The fact pattern is defined by two parties having a right of self-defense simultaneously. On the one hand, you have a home defender who can rightfully use deadly force under the castle doctrine. On the other hand you have cops doing their job, who have the right to defend themselves pursuant to a lawful warrant. ”Justice” doesn’t always mean that guilt exists whenever tragedy occurs. If the Louisville, KY prosecutor’s grand jury told him he couldn’t get a conviction given this messy fact pattern, then it was just not to press charges from a procedural perspective. Her family received a $15,000,000.00 settlement. A lot of times the difference between “preponderance of the evidence” as a standard in a civil case for damages and “beyond a reasonable doubt” as a standard in a criminal case is outcome-determinative. O.J. was acquitted in criminal court but found liable in the wrongful death case. The legal standard of evidence matters a great deal. In a messy case like this, a verdict of guilty based on proof beyond a reasonable doubt is hard enough to come by that I don’t question the prosecutor’s decision.

If this evidence is true, it was just: Officers entered the home pursuant to a valid warrant Breonna’s boyfriend shot at the officers or otherwise showed the ability to use deadly force Officers responded in self defense Breonna was struck by a bullet discharged during that self defense

The problem is we don’t know the evidence until it is presented in the court case. Basing an opinion on media coverage is just not viable. I suspect however that someone was not using appropriately safe fire discipline.
I haven’t seen the evidence, and neither have you.
